content.explanation:
Function notation is particularly useful in real-world applications where we need to model relationships between variables.

For example, if C(x) represents the cost of producing x items, then C(100) would be the cost of producing 100 items.

Similarly, if h(t) represents the height of a ball t seconds after being thrown, then h(2) would be the height after 2 seconds.
content.example: If P(n) = 15n - 200 represents the profit (in dollars) from selling n t-shirts, then P(50) = 15(50) - 200 = 750 - 200 = $550 is the profit from selling 50 t-shirts.
content.key_point: In real-world contexts, the variables and function names often have specific meanings. Pay attention to the units and what each variable represents.

interactive.question: If D(s) = 0.10s + 5 represents the delivery fee (in dollars) for an order costing s dollars, what is the delivery fee for an order of $30?
